values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

This was created from the comment in [0].  I agree that this is a take-away from operators who want to rename their admin role to something else.  Will see what other say; marking this -WF for now.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384655/

Patch Set 5:

ok, that makes more sense... so let's take a step back and talk about these two places separately:
1) scrubber.py: This appears to be making a fake context that it will then use to pass policy checks on things it needs to do. It shouldn't really need admin_role to do that. Either it needs credentials that it can send to keystone to get a real token (which would obviously include role information without the need for an admin_role conf setting), or it needs to do things in a way that skips policy checks.
2) api/middleware/context.py: As you pointed out, is_admin will be set (correctly) when the RequestContext constructor is called a few lines later if we don't pre-set it here, so I don't really see the point in setting it based on admin_role here. That makes my wonder why this was written... does it perhaps predate a change in the RequestContext constructor to set is_admin based on context_is_admin policy, or are we missing something? Someone with more glance history should look at this.

Patch Set 5:

For 1) I will revisit the scrubber.py issue later. 2) I will defer that to folks who has more glance history to answer - but I was thinking it was coded as a mean to provide admin-role to a role with some user-defined string.

Patch Set 5:

If you're right about #2, the obvious question is "why?"... The context_is_admin policy check is supposed to do that.

If it wasn't for this conf setting also being used in scrubber, I would say yes, deprecate it and then stop using it in the middleware in a future release. But we can't deprecate it while it's still needed for the scrubber, so I think you'll have to take these together. Unless the glance cores think it's ok to just remove it from the middleware today and potentially break an operator that has set admin_role to something different from context_is_admin, but I doubt they would do that.
